remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Good morning, thank you for coming in today. I understand you’ve been experiencing acute left-sided back pain and shortness of breath with exertion. Can you describe in more detail how your back pain started and if anything makes it better or worse?

remedi_labels.value: factors that make pain better or worse

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Um, good morning. Yes, it’s really the left-sided back pain that’s bothering me the most right now. It kind of came on suddenly, and I’m not sure what brought it on. I just noticed it got pretty sharp all of a sudden. I’m a bit worried about it, to be honest.

I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—sudden, sharp back pain can be very concerning. To help guide my assessment, can you tell me if your back pain radiates to your chest or abdomen, or if you’ve noticed any other symptoms such as fever, numbness, or weakness?

remedi_labels.value: back pain radiates to chest or abdomen

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… I don’t think the pain really spreads to my chest or abdomen, it mostly just stays in my back on the left side. I have noticed my breathing feels kind of shallow, and, um, I think there are some odd sounds—like rattling—when I breathe in and out. I’m just worried because it feels harder to catch my breath than usual.

remedi_labels.value: pain in back on the left side

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially with the sudden onset of sharp back pain and difficulty breathing. To help guide my assessment, can you tell me if your shortness of breath is worse when you’re lying down or during activity, and whether you’ve noticed any swelling in your legs or feet recently?

remedi_labels.value: sudden onset of sharp back pain
shortness of breath worse when lying down or during activity

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Um, let me think… The shortness of breath definitely gets worse when I’m up and moving around—like, even just walking to the bathroom makes me feel winded. I don’t notice it as much when I’m lying down, but sometimes I still feel a little out of breath. And actually, now that you mention it, my legs and feet have been more swollen lately. I also had a bit of chest pain, but I wasn’t sure if it was related or not. Should I be worried about all these symptoms together?

remedi_labels.value: shortness of breath worsens with activity
shortness of breath sometimes at rest
Should I be worried about all these symptoms together?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially with the combination of acute back pain, shortness of breath, and increased swelling in your legs. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any changes in your urine output or color, or any symptoms such as blood in your urine or difficulty urinating?

Um… I haven’t really noticed any big changes with my urine, I don’t think. No blood or anything like that, and I’m still able to go, though maybe a little less than usual. Actually, now that I think about it, I’ve also had some acute shortness of breath—like, it comes on pretty suddenly sometimes. And, uh, I’ve been having this crampy abdominal pain off and on too. I’m just not sure if all these symptoms are connected, but it’s making me pretty anxious.

remedi_labels.value: able to urinate, but less than usual
crampy abdominal pain off and on

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious with these new and persistent symptoms. To help guide my assessment, have you experienced any fevers, chills, or night sweats along with your acute back pain and shortness of breath?

Um, yes, actually—I have had a bit of a fever on and off, and sometimes I feel kind of chilled, but not really night sweats. The shortness of breath, or dyspnea with exertion I guess you’d call it, has definitely gotten worse lately. And the swelling in my legs and feet—what you called chronic lower extremity edema—that’s been more noticeable too. I’m just feeling pretty anxious about all these symptoms happening together.

I can understand why you’d be anxious with these symptoms, especially since your lower extremity edema has worsened and you’re experiencing acute left-sided back pain. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any redness, warmth, or tenderness in your legs, or any skin changes over the areas where the swelling is most pronounced?

Let me think… I haven’t really noticed much redness or warmth in my legs, and I don’t think there’s any tenderness either—just the swelling, mostly. The skin looks about the same, maybe just a little stretched from the edema. 

Actually, I wanted to mention something else that’s been worrying me. I’ve been feeling kind of mild respiratory distress—not just shortness of breath, but like I have to work harder to breathe. And when I was touching around my back, near my armpits, I felt this crackly sensation under the skin—I think you call it crepitus? It’s on both sides, over the posterior axillae. Is that something serious? Should I be worried about that?

remedi_labels.value: no redness, warmth, or tenderness in legs; swelling present; skin stretched from edema
mild respiratory distress; increased work of breathing
crackly sensation (crepitus) under skin over posterior axillae, bilateral
Is crepitus something serious? Should I be worried?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with the combination of acute left-sided back pain, worsening lower extremity edema, and now the sensation of crepitus under your skin. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any changes in your voice, difficulty swallowing, or coughing up blood along with these respiratory symptoms?

Well, um, actually, after I was extubated last time, I did have some trouble swallowing—like, it felt kind of hard to get symptoms down for a bit. My voice has been a little hoarse off and on, but I haven’t coughed up any blood. 

The swelling in my legs is definitely worse—I think you’d call it 1+ pitting edema on both sides. And this feeling of respiratory distress is really making me anxious. Sometimes I feel like I just can’t get a deep breath at all. Is all of this connected? Should I be worried that it’s something serious with my lungs or heart?

I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially with your history of respiratory and cardiac involvement from amyloidosis. To help guide my assessment, have you noticed any new or worsening orthopnea—meaning difficulty breathing when lying flat—or episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, where you wake up suddenly at night short of breath?

remedi_labels.value: respiratory and cardiac involvement from amyloidosis

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Um, yes, actually—I have noticed some orthopnea lately. It’s gotten harder to breathe when I’m lying flat, so I’ve been propping myself up with extra pillows at night. I haven’t really had full episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, but sometimes I do wake up feeling a bit short of breath.

Also, I wanted to mention that when I try to walk around—even just a little bit—my oxygen saturations drop into the mid 80s. The dyspnea on exertion has definitely gotten worse. I’m really anxious about all these symptoms, especially with my history of amyloidosis in the lungs and heart. Is this something that could be related to my underlying disease, or should I be worried about something new like a pneumothorax or heart failure?

remedi_labels.value: oxygen saturations drop into the mid 80s with exertion
amyloidosis in the lungs and heart
relation of symptoms to underlying disease or new condition such as pneumothorax or heart failure

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um, I haven’t really had much of a cough or sputum production, and no real night sweats—just those chills and the fevers I mentioned. But actually, something else happened that’s made me even more anxious. I had two really large, grossly bloody bowel movements recently. With everything else going on—the acute left-sided back pain, the dyspnea on exertion, the edema, the hypotension, and now this GI bleeding—I’m honestly pretty worried. Is it possible all these symptoms are connected? Should I be concerned about something serious happening with my underlying amyloidosis, or could this be a complication from my medications or something new entirely?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with the combination of acute left-sided back pain, worsening dyspnea on exertion, lower extremity edema, hypotension, fevers, and now new lower gastroindiagnostic evaluationinal bleeding. These symptoms could be related to your underlying amyloidosis, possible cardiac or pulmonary involvement, or even complications from your medications such as anticoagulation. To help guide my assessment, have you noticed any dizziness, lightheadedness, or episodes of fainting associated with your recent hypotension or GI bleeding?

Yes, actually—I have had some episodes of dizziness and lightheadedness, especially when I stand up or after those big, bloody bowel movements. I haven’t fully fainted, but I’ve definitely felt like I might a couple of times. The hypotension seems to come and go, but it’s been more noticeable lately.

Also, just to mention again, after my last extubation I had some swallowing difficulties—it was hard to get symptoms down for a while, and my voice was a bit hoarse. I’m not sure if that’s related to what’s happening now, but with all these symptoms—like the acute left-sided back pain, dyspnea on exertion, edema, hypotension, fever, and now the lower GI bleed—I’m really anxious. 

Is there a chance all of this could be connected to my amyloidosis or one of my medications, like the coumadin? Should I be worried about something like a pneumothorax or heart failure right now? And do you think I need more tests or imaging to figure out what’s going on?

I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially given your history of amyloidosis, anticoagulation with coumadin, and the recent onset of acute left-sided back pain, dyspnea on exertion, edema, hypotension, fever, and now a lower GI bleed. Based on your symptoms and medical history, it is possible that these findings are interconnected—potentially related to cardiac or pulmonary involvement from amyloidosis, bleeding complications from anticoagulation, or even an acute process like pneumothorax or heart failure.

My clinical assessment is that you need urgent medical evaluation, including chest imaging (such as a chest X-ray or CT scan), laboratory studies to assess for anemia and coagulation status, and possibly an echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac function. In addition, monitoring your vital signs and oxygen saturation closely is important.

Have you had your most recent INR (a diagnostic evaluation to monitor blood thinning from coumadin) examineed since the onset of your GI bleeding and hypotension?
